column1: County Wexford (Irish: Contae Loch Garman) is a county in Ireland. It is in the province of Leinster and is part of the South-East Region. Named after the town of Wexford
column2: it was based on the historic Gaelic territory of Hy Kinsella (Uí Ceinnsealaigh)
column3: whose capital was Ferns. Wexford County Council is the local authority for the county. The population of the county was 149

column1: The county is rich in evidence of early human habitation. Portal tombs (sometimes called dolmens) exist at Ballybrittas (on Bree Hill) and at Newbawn — and date from the Neolithic period or earlier. Remains from the Bronze Age period are far more widespread. Early Irish tribes formed the Kingdom of Uí Cheinnsealaig
column2: an area that was slightly larger than the current County Wexford.

column1: County Wexford was one of the earliest areas of Ireland to be Christianised
column2: in the early 5th century. Later
column3: from 819 onwards
column4: the Vikings invaded and plundered many Christian sites in the county. Vikings settled at Wexford town near the end of the 9th century.In 1169
column5: Wexford was the site of the invasion of Ireland by Normans at the behest of Diarmuid Mac Murrough
column6: King of Uí Cheinnsealaig and king of Leinster (Laigin). This was followed by the subsequent colonisation of the country by the Anglo-Normans.

column1: The native Irish began to regain some of their former territories in the 14th century
column2: especially in the north of the county
column3: principally under Art MacMurrough Kavanagh. Under Henry VIII
column4: the great religious houses were dissolved
column5: 1536–41; in County Wexford this included Glascarrig Priory
column6: Clonmines Priory

column2: a major rebellion broke out in Ireland
column3: and County Wexford produced strong support for Confederate Ireland. Oliver Cromwell and his English Parliamentarian Army arrived in 1649 in the county and captured it. The lands of the Irish and Anglo-Normans were confiscated and given to Cromwell's soldiers as payment for their service in the Parliamentarian Army. At Duncannon
column4: in the south-west of the county
column5: James II
column6: after his defeat at the Battle of the Boyne
column7: embarked for Kinsale and then to exile in France.

column1: County Wexford was the most important area in which the Irish Rebellion of 1798 was fought
column2: during which significant battles occurred at The Battle of Oulart Hill during the 1798 rebellion. Vinegar Hill (Enniscorthy) and New Ross. The famous ballad "Boolavogue" was written in remembrance of the Wexford Rising. At Easter 1916
column3: a small rebellion occurred at Enniscorthy town
column4: on cue with that in Dublin. During World War II
column5: German planes bombed Campile. In 1963 John F. Kennedy
column6: then President of the United States
column7: visited the county and his ancestral home at Dunganstown

column1: Wexford is the 13th largest of Ireland's thirty-two counties in area
column2: and 14th largest in terms of population. It is the largest of Leinster's 12 counties in size
column3: and fourth largest in terms of population. The county is located in the south-east corner of the island of Ireland. It is bounded by the sea on two sides—on the south by the Atlantic Ocean and on the east by St. George's Channel and the Irish Sea. The River Barrow forms its western boundary. The Blackstairs Mountains form part of the boundary to the north
column4: as do the southern edges of the Wicklow Mountains. The adjoining counties are Waterford
column5: Kilkenny
column6: Carlow and Wicklow.

column1: County Wexford is known as Ireland's "sunny southeast" because
column2: in general
column3: the number of hours of sunshine received daily is higher than in the rest of the country. This has resulted in Wexford becoming one of the most popular places in Ireland in which to reside. The county has a mild
column5: oceanic climate with few extremes. The North Atlantic Drift
column6: a continuation of the Gulf Stream
column7: moderates winter temperatures. There is a meteorological station located at Rosslare Harbour. January and February are generally the coldest months
column8: with temperatures ranging from 4–8 °C (39–46 °F) on average. July and August are generally the warmest months
column9: with temperatures ranging from 12–18 °C (54–64 °F) on average. The prevailing winds are from the south-west. Precipitation falls throughout the year. Mean annual rainfall is 800–1
column11: the county receives less snow than more northerly parts of Ireland. Heavy snowfalls are relatively rare
column12: but can occur. The one exception is Mount Leinster
column13: visible from a large portion of the county
column14: which is frequently covered with snow during the winter months. Frost is frequent in winter months

column1: Largely low-lying fertile land is the characteristic landscape of the county. The highest point in the county is Mount Leinster at 795 metres (2
column3: in the Blackstairs Mountains in the north-west on the boundary with County Carlow.
965 ft). It is located near the Wexford-Carlow border

column1: The major rivers are the Slaney and the Barrow. At 192 km (119 mi) in length
column2: the river Barrow is the second-longest river on the island of Ireland. Smaller rivers of note are the Owenduff
column3: Pollmounty
column5: Urrin
column6: Boro

column1: There are no significant fresh-water lakes in the county. Small seaside lakes or lagoons exist at two locations – one is called Lady's Island Lake and the other Tacumshin Lake.
The Wexford Cot is a flat-bottomed boat used for fishing on the tidal mudflats in Wexford
column2: also a canoe shaped Punt fitted with a gun
column3: called a Float in Wexford is used traditionally to shoot game birds in the North Slob mud flats.

column1: The Saltee Islands lie 5 km (3 mi) offshore from Kilmore Quay
column2: while the smaller Keeragh Islands are 1.5 km (1 mi) offshore from Bannow.
but not all
column3: of the county was covered with the ice sheet during the last Ice age. As the ice retreated
column4: County Wexford would have been one of the first areas to be covered with glacial drift (a mixture of boulders
column5: clay
column6: sand and gravel) that blanketed the existing bedrock. This has led to high quality soils
column7: suitable for a wide range of agriculture. A very detailed soil survey of the county was published in 1964
column8: as part of the 'National Soil Survey of Ireland'. It classifies each area of the county according to its specific soil type.Most of the county is covered with soil called brown earths
column9: described as well-drained and having a wide use range. After that
column10: gleys (poorly to imperfectly drained with a limited use range) are the next major soil type
column11: primarily located in the south-east of the county and east of Gorey (along the coast). Gleys are dotted elsewhere around the county in small areas
column12: and where they occur they generally form bogland. The last major soil type is brown podzolics
column13: located mainly near the edges of the Blackstairs Mountain range and around Bunclody and in the baronies of East Shelmalier and South Ballaghkeen. Though there are areas covered with other soil types

column1: Common species of tree include oak
column2: ash
column3: sycamore
column5: blackthorn
column6: hawthorn
column7: beech and birch. Less common (but plentiful) are wild cherry and Scots pine (also called red deal). Elm is now far less common
column8: due to the devastating effects of Dutch elm disease. Gorse (or furze) is very common. A priority habitat in Wexford is the grey dune
column9: on which many native wild flora grow
column10: including bee orchid and pyramidal orchid. Despite the designation of much of this habitat as a Special Area of Conservation
column11: it remains threatened by destruction for agricultural intensification. There is very little natural forest in the county. Most natural trees and vegetation grow on hedgerows.

column1: South-eastern Wexford is an important site for wild birds—the north side of Wexford Harbour
column2: the North Slob
column3: is home to 10
column4: 000 Greenland white-fronted geese each winter (roughly one third of the entire world's population)
column5: while in the summer Lady's Island Lake is an important breeding site for terns
column6: especially the roseate tern. The grey heron is also seen.

column2: woodpigeon and feral pigeons are widespread. Mute swan
column3: mallard
column5: and owls (the long-eared owl
column6: the short-eared owl
column7: and the barn owl) are less common - but plentiful. Red grouse
column9: is now extremely scarce. The species has been in decline for some decades. Threats include habitat degradation
column11: predation and over-hunting. Red grouse in Ireland are now considered threatened. The corncrake
column13: is now almost never seen. Smaller birds—such as crows
column16: wrens and so on—are very common. The first magpies in Ireland were recorded by Robert Leigh
column19: as having appeared in the County of Wexford about 1676.

column2: rabbit
column3: otter
column5: red fox
column6: mink
column9: rats (brown and black - both introduced species)
column10: and mice (wood (or field) and house). Two types of hare—the Irish (or mountain) hare and the less common brown (or European) hare—are found. Hare is not nearly as common as rabbit. The stoat (Mustela erminea hibernica) is also reasonably common. Locally the stoat is just as often incorrectly called a weasel.

column1: Only two types of seal are found on County Wexford's coast—Atlantic grey seals are very plentiful in coastal areas
column2: but the slightly smaller common (or harbour) seal is less common
column3: yet plentiful. The small tortoiseshell butterfly (reddish-orange colour
column4: with black markings) is the most common species of butterfly in the county. Various types of moth are also common. The common frog is plentiful
column5: and is the only type of frog found.

column1: Wexford County Council has thirty-four members. The Wexford constituency is represented by five deputies in Dáil Éireann: James Browne (FF)
column2: Paul Kehoe (FG)
column3: Brendan Howlin (Lab)
column4: Michael W. D'Arcy (FG) and Mick Wallace (Ind).

column2: an opera festival
column3: Wexford Festival Opera
column4: takes place every year in the Theatre Royal in Wexford town and runs for several weeks. In 2008
column5: a new Opera House replaced the old one on the same site
column6: once called the Wexford Opera House
column7: but in 2014 being designated as Ireland's National Opera House. It consists of two theatres
column8: the O'Reilly Theatre and the Jerome Hynes Theatre.

column1: There is a renowned singing tradition in County Wexford. Having an abundance of traditional songs
column2: many of which relate to the rebellion of 1798
column3: the county has for many years had a strong presence in the Irish traditional singing scene. Noted singers include All-Ireland Fleadh Champions Paddy Berry
column4: Seamus Brogan and Niall Wall. Paddy Berry has also collected and published a number of songs from Wexford.

column2: County Wexford were used to film the opening scenes of the movie Saving Private Ryan
column3: which depicted the D-day assault on Omaha Beach. The Count of Monte Cristo
column5: was partly filmed in the village of Duncannon in 2000 — Duncannon Fort being used for one of the main scenes. The movie Brooklyn (film) was partially filmed in Enniscorthy and featured some of the locals as extras.

column2: located near Duncormick

column1: The Hook Peninsula is noted for its many beaches and spectacular scenery. It features the medieval Hook Head lighthouse and the historic townland of Loftus Hall.
Popular beaches are located at Courtown
column2: Curracloe
column3: Carnsore Point

column1: The economy is chiefly agricultural. Cattle
column2: sheep
column3: pig rearing and some horse breeding are the main types of husbandry practiced. Poultry rearing
column5: has very much declined. Wheat
column6: barley
column9: as are potatoes. Sugar beet is no longer grown due to the withdrawal of EU subsidies. The numbers involved in farming have been declining for many years and many of the seasonal workers are now eastern Europeans. Mushrooms are also grown indoors. Tomatoes are grown under glass

column1: Wexford strawberries are famous and can be bought in shops and wayside stalls throughout the summer. Every year
column2: near the end of June
column3: a 'Strawberry Fair' Festival takes place in the town of Enniscorthy
column4: and a Strawberry Queen is crowned. Dairy farming forms an important part of the agricultural industry. Locally produced milk is on sale in many supermarkets. Wexford Irish Cheddar is an award-winning brand
column5: and Carrigbyrne
column6: a full-flavoured soft cheese

column1: Evergreen tree species are extensively cultivated
column2: especially in more recent years—Norway spruce and Sitka spruce are the most common varieties planted. These are generally sown on poorer quality soils (mainly in bogs and on hills or mountainsides). A small amount of deciduous trees are also planted
column3: though these require better soils.

column1: Silver was once mined at Clonmines—primarily in Tudor times. Lead was mined at Caim
column2: 1818 - c. 1850—this mine also contains zinc; the two are usually found together. Copper ore (malachite) is found at Kerloge
column3: just south of the town of Wexford. Iron is found in small quantities at Courtown Harbour. The county is not noted for mineral reserves. No significant mining activity is currently practised
column4: with the exception of quarrying for stone. In 2007
column5: a significant oil find was made 60 km (37 mi) off Hook Head in County Wexford.

column1: Carnsore Point made the national headlines in the late 1970s after a proposal was made to build a nuclear energy plant there; the plans were abandoned after extensive protests from the public
column2: due to environmental and health concerns.

column1: Great Island Power Station opened in 1967 and was operated by the Electricity Supply Board (ESB) until it was sold to Endesa in January 2009.  It is an electricity-generating station fueled by heavy fuel oil and rated at 240 MW.  It is located at the confluence of the rivers Barrow and Suir
column2: near Campile. Before its sale
column3: the station was scheduled to close by 2010. Endesa propose building a 430 MW combined cycle gas turbine (CCGT) gas fired plant on the site.  The project would need a new 44.5 km (27.7 mi) gas pipeline from the existing transmission network at Baunlusk
column4: 6 km (3.7 mi) south of Kilkenny City. A wind farm has now been built on the site
column5: featuring 14 wind turbines generating electricity. It was completed in November 2002 and was the first wind farm on the east coast of Ireland. Wind farms now exist at a few other locations in the county
column6: such as Ballywater Wind Farm
column10: located in the southeast of the county.
